Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating Novel Algal-Sludge Granules for Wastewater Treatment and Biomethane Feedstock Generation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1335816
Chul Park
University of Massachusetts Amherst

Most municipalities in the US currently use the activated sludge process to treat wastewater. The process achieves secondary treatment but is energy intensive, mainly due to its need of aeration for organic matter and nutrient treatment. Interest in algae-based wastewater treatment has increased in recent years because of its ability to treat wastewater without aeration through the symbiotic growth of photosynthetic algae and bacteria and generate biofuel feedstock. Despite these benefits, the lack of microalgae bioflocculation, which accounts for the difficulty in separating biomass from water, and an inability to control algal species in the wastewater environment have hindered the development of algae processes for wastewater treatment. The objective of this research is to elucidate biogranulation of microalgae and bacteria that yields novel algal-sludge granules. These granules are large, dense, and spherical bioaggregates composed of both microalgae and bacteria. Preliminary research has found that algal-sludge granules can be naturally formed in the wastewater environment and be used for treating wastewater in a flow-through bioreactor. Due to physical characteristics, granules readily separate out from water, overcoming one of the major challenges of algae processes. In addition, symbiosis of algae and bacteria within the same granular biomass facilitates the engineering of an algae process for wastewater and nutrient treatment. To unveil the mechanisms of biogranulation of microalgae and bacteria this research will employ a series of batch and a flow-through reactor studies and investigate the effect of light, temperature, and growth rates on algal-bacterial granulation. To determine the microbiological nature and characterize physiochemical properties of algal-sludge granules, the investigators will conduct genetic, microscopic, and physicochemical analyses on the biogranules through this research. The project will also use a compliment of microsensor approaches to document the transport of key metabolic chemicals across the granules, thus studying microbial activity and function of the granules and their link to wastewater treatment performances. Finally, the research will conduct anaerobic digestion study on harvested biogranules to investigate its fate, digestibility, and methane bioenergy yield by anaerobic digestion, especially compared to other feedstock, such as sewage sludge and pure cultures of algal biomass.

The contribution of this research will reveal the fundamental science behind the development of novel algal-sludge granules and their growth in the context of real wastewater treatment. This research is significant, because biogranules of algae and bacteria will result in a controllable and effective algae-based wastewater treatment process. Additionally, the symbiotic growth of algae and bacteria will lead to meaningful biomass yield for biofeedstock generation from wastewater treatment. Collectively, the outcome of this research will not only advance the field of wastewater treatment, it will also have a substantially broad impact and benefit to society by reducing the energy consumed during wastewater treatment and increasing opportunity to recover chemical energy of wastewater in the form of bioenergy feedstock and biomethane through its anaerobic digestion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has enabled us to investigate a photogranulation phenomenon in which hybrid biogranules, containing phototrophic and non-phototrophic biomass, are formed in a static environment. Based on numerous cultivation experiments with microbial ecology analysis (e.g., MiSeq DNA sequencing), advanced microscopy, and physicochemical characterization, we demonstrated that this photogranulation is a universal phenomenon and can take place in widely varying environments. This project has unveiled the right static cultivation conditions as well as the key groups of phototrophic microorganisms that are necessary to produce photogranules. This project also determined the flux of key chemicals within photogranules, which helped us to better understand the microbial function and physiology of these novel biogranules. Another outcome of this project is that we have been able to operate the lab-scale oxygenic photogranule (OPG) systems for wastewater treatment (Figure 1) for an extended period of time, greater than a year, indicating our improved knowledge about this new bioprocess. Through static cultivation and bioreactor studies, we could identify common and different characteristics of photogranules generated from two very different conditions. Finally, results from the energy balance analysis and anaerobic digestion of photogranules have revealed that the OPG process has the potential to recover chemical energy in wastewater in the form of high-quality biofeedstock and that anaerobic digestion is a viable option to recover energy from the harvested photogranule biomass. 

Though at the moment the OPG process is in lab and pilot-scale demonstration, it is able to treat wastewater without aeration, which currently causes the highest energy demand in wastewater treatment in the developed world. Due to the photoautotrophic assimilation of CO2, the OPG system can also recover wastewater’s chemical energy in the form of easily harvestable biofeedstock. Therefore, the OPG process has the potential to substantially reduce costs for wastewater treatment and generate enough energy to turn wastewater treatment plants into energy positive water resource recovery facilities. Consequently, successful development of the OPG process to an industrial scale can potentially change how we treat wastewater around the world.

Due to the universal and ubiquitous phenomenon of photogranulation, results from our research can benefit photogranule and biofilm research in other disciplines, such as environmental microbiology, microbial ecology, geobiology, paleogeology, and earth science. Indeed, one of the primary outcomes of this project is that we can translate photogranulation of activated sludge, which may be substantially relevant to other photogranules that are formed in natural environments.  

The current NSF research project also gave birth to our national and international collaboration that enhanced dissemination of the OPG research. Currently, eleven senior researchers and their research groups are working together on OPGs and the OPG-based wastewater treatment. These researchers are from eight institutions in four countries, which are: 1) UMass Amherst (Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering; Department of Microbiology) 2) INRA-LBE (Narbonne, France); 3) University of Hawaii at Manoa; 4) Inha University (Incheon, Korea); 5) Dongkuk University (Seoul, Korea); 6) University of Nairobi (Nairobi, Kenya); and 7) Hampton Roads Sanitation District. The current project also became the foundation of new research opportunities. The new OPG research that we have obtained during the current research project period include: 1) NSF CAREER Award to the Co-PI Butler; 2) NSF GOALI Award to the PIs Park and Butler with their industry partner Co-PI Dr. Wilson from Hampton Roads Sanitation District; 3) ANR JCJC Award (France) to the collaborator Dr. Kim Milferstedt, which is a companion research project of PIs Park and Butler’s NSF GOALI; and 4) multiple seed funds to PI Park for the pilot testing and technology development for industrial use. 

This project has provided numerous research opportunities to a group of undergraduate and graduate students (four doctoral and two master students). Many of these students represent underrepresented groups. During this project, four Ph.D. students received prestigious research awards for their innovative research on OPGs, which include: 1) NSF Graduate Fellowship; 2) Chateaubriand Fellowship from the Embassy of France in the U.S., which allowed the student to conduct visiting research at INRA-LBE in 2016; 3) Pakistan National Fellowship; and 4) Egyptian National Scholarship. These students continue to work for their doctoral degrees in Environmental Engineering and have actively presented their studies by submission of research manuscripts and presentations at conferences. This project has also hosted and given research opportunities to six high-school students from various areas in Massachusetts. 

Finally, the international patent application has been filed and the team is working with the private company to facilitate the commercialization of the OPG process for wastewater treatment. Along with a new NSF GOALI grant opportunity, we expect that this new academe and industry collaboration will facilitate the technology transfer and industrial development of OPG research.
